content:
IS lass="word-wrap-span">INDIA, the world’s lass="word-wrap-span">largest democracy, a liberal democracy? lass="word-wrap-span">This is the question that people both inside and outside of the country are increasingly asking. lass="word-wrap-span">Since gaining power in 2014 and lass="word-wrap-span">cementing it in elections last lass="word-wrap-span">May, lass="word-wrap-span">Prime lass="word-wrap-span">Minister Narendra Modi has governed as if lass="word-wrap-span">Hindus are the only real lass="word-wrap-span">INDIAns.

Sagarika Ghose, a journalist and television lass="word-wrap-span">anchor, offers an lass="word-wrap-span">indictment of the current politics and a rallying cry for an alternative, with her lass="word-wrap-span">book: “lass="word-wrap-span">Why I Am a lass="word-wrap-span">Liberal: A lass="word-wrap-span">Manifesto for lass="word-wrap-span">Indians lass="word-wrap-span">Who lass="word-wrap-span">Believe in lass="word-wrap-span">Individual lass="word-wrap-span">Freedom” (lass="word-wrap-span">Penguin lass="word-wrap-span">Random lass="word-wrap-span">House, 2018).

As part of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Economist ’s lass="word-wrap-span">Open lass="word-wrap-span">Future lass="word-wrap-span">initiative, we asked Ms Ghose some questions about liberalism in lass="word-wrap-span">India. lass="word-wrap-span">After lass="word-wrap-span">The interview we publish an lass="word-wrap-span">excerpt from her lass="word-wrap-span">book.

* * *

lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Economist: lass="word-wrap-span">You wrote a 397-page lass="word-wrap-span">book lass="word-wrap-span">entitled "lass="word-wrap-span">Why I Am a liberal". In a few sentences, please explain: lass="word-wrap-span">Why, in fact, are lass="word-wrap-span">You a liberal?

Sagarika Ghose: I’m a liberal because I believe in the ideal that aims for greater social, political and economic freedom for the individual as against the massive, lass="word-wrap-span">coercive powers of a centralised “lass="word-wrap-span">Big lass="word-wrap-span">State”. In 2014 the right-wing lass="word-wrap-span">Hindu nationalist lass="word-wrap-span">Party, the Bharatiya Janata lass="word-wrap-span">Party, as lass="word-wrap-span">hardliners, won a full majority under the leadership of lass="word-wrap-span">Prime lass="word-wrap-span">Minister Narendra Modi. It returned to power this year with an even lass="word-wrap-span">Bigger majority and an even more lass="word-wrap-span">belligerent, lass="word-wrap-span">ideological agenda.

lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Economist: In your lass="word-wrap-span">book, you argue that traditional liberalism aligns with classical lass="word-wrap-span">Indian values and history. lass="word-wrap-span">Please explain.

Ms Ghose: Yes, I lass="word-wrap-span">audaciously link liberal values to spiritual-religious traditions in lass="word-wrap-span">India to argue that values of individual freedom can’t be lass="word-wrap-span">dismissed as mere lass="word-wrap-span">imitations of the lass="word-wrap-span">West or part of the lass="word-wrap-span">colonial lass="word-wrap-span">hangover from the British lass="word-wrap-span">Raj. It is wrong to demonise the quest for individual freedom as just the lass="word-wrap-span">elitist lass="word-wrap-span">creed of those whom nationalists’ attack as lass="word-wrap-span">Macaulay-putras (or “children of lass="word-wrap-span">Macaulay,” that is, lass="word-wrap-span">Western-educated lass="word-wrap-span">Indian lass="word-wrap-span">elites). lass="word-wrap-span">This is because the lass="word-wrap-span">Hindu religion—and the present regime calls itself a defender of lass="word-wrap-span">Hindus—places a big lass="word-wrap-span">emphasis on individual freedom.

lass="word-wrap-span">The seeker seeks alone, lass="word-wrap-span">There’s no single church, instead a lass="word-wrap-span">dizzying variety of sects and rituals and almost nothing is talass="word-wrap-span">boo. lass="word-wrap-span">Indian liberals believe that lass="word-wrap-span">Gandhi, drawing on lass="word-wrap-span">These traditions, was lass="word-wrap-span">India’s lass="word-wrap-span">greatest liberal because his political philosophy was centered lass="word-wrap-span">entirely on lass="word-wrap-span">The individual. So perhaps ancient lass="word-wrap-span">Hindus were liberals long before classical liberalism lass="word-wrap-span">emerged in lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">West in lass="word-wrap-span">The 19th century!

lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Economist: lass="word-wrap-span">How is liberalism under lass="word-wrap-span">assault in lass="word-wrap-span">India?

Ms Ghose: lass="word-wrap-span">Liberalism is under grave lass="word-wrap-span">assault. lass="word-wrap-span">Students and writers have been charged under lass="word-wrap-span">antiquated sedition laws. In the lass="word-wrap-span">guise of protecting lass="word-wrap-span">cattle, lynch mobs are attacking lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims with lass="word-wrap-span">impunity. lass="word-wrap-span">Cow-protecting vigilantes target lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims as “lass="word-wrap-span">cattle smugglers”. A citizens’ group which recently protested against these mob lynchings was viciously trolled on social media and trenchantly criticised by ruling-party politicians. lass="word-wrap-span">When strongman politicians lass="word-wrap-span">deploy violent speech in castigating lass="word-wrap-span">dissenters and critics as “traitors”, street mobs become lass="word-wrap-span">emboldened to carry out physical attacks.

lass="word-wrap-span">Rationalist intellectuals who campaigned against orthodoxy, such as M.M. Kalburgi, Narendra Dabholkar and Govind Pansare, have been shot dead and their murders linked to lass="word-wrap-span">Certain ultra-lass="word-wrap-span">Hindu outfits. My friend, the left-liberal journalist Gauri Lankesh, was shot and lass="word-wrap-span">killed two years ago. lass="word-wrap-span">Academics are often targeted by the student wing of the ruling party. lass="word-wrap-span">Certain lass="word-wrap-span">books and films are banned. lass="word-wrap-span">Right-wing television channels—“lass="word-wrap-span">Fox lass="word-wrap-span">News on steroids”—regularly whip up public lass="word-wrap-span">hatred against liberals.

lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Economist: lass="word-wrap-span">What can be done in lass="word-wrap-span">India to overcome lass="word-wrap-span">These challenges and support lass="word-wrap-span">The liberal cause?

Ms Ghose: lass="word-wrap-span">Liberals in lass="word-wrap-span">India need to be really, really brave; be prepared for attacks and undertake collective action to push their cause. lass="word-wrap-span">Perhaps a lass="word-wrap-span">Liberal revival can be created if lass="word-wrap-span">Liberals move out of their comfort zones and engage with people across the country on why freedom and liberty are important. It’s very difficult in lass="word-wrap-span">India because the lass="word-wrap-span">State—what I call the “lass="word-wrap-span">Big lass="word-wrap-span">State”—is so overbearing and lass="word-wrap-span">intrusive that everyone is scrambling for pieces of the government pie.

lass="word-wrap-span">Most are terrified to speak out even if their freedoms have been seriously lass="word-wrap-span">curtailed. lass="word-wrap-span">Liberals too have mistakenly sought state power to push their objectives and made the mistake of themselves becoming lass="word-wrap-span">intolerant of lass="word-wrap-span">dissent. As a path to revival, lass="word-wrap-span">Indian lass="word-wrap-span">Liberals are now calling for a return to studying lass="word-wrap-span">Gandhi. lass="word-wrap-span">Little is popularly known about lass="word-wrap-span">Gandhi’s lass="word-wrap-span">fundamental lass="word-wrap-span">affinity with individual freedom and his respect for lass="word-wrap-span">dissent and difference.

lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Economist: lass="word-wrap-span">One of lass="word-wrap-span">The most moving sections of your lass="word-wrap-span">book is on lass="word-wrap-span">feminism in lass="word-wrap-span">India. lass="word-wrap-span">How bad are things and what can be dlass="word-wrap-span">One to improve lass="word-wrap-span">The situation?

Ms Ghose: lass="word-wrap-span">Things are bad. lass="word-wrap-span">Violence, lass="word-wrap-span">harassment and lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination against women are pretty rampant. lass="word-wrap-span">The recently published sex ratio—number of females to every 1,000 males—is deeply worrying: lass="word-wrap-span">The number of women declined to 896 in 2015-17 from 898 in 2014-16. lass="word-wrap-span">Even rich, educated families opt for male children and secretly lass="word-wrap-span">abort female fetuses. lass="word-wrap-span">India is a sun-worshipping and son-worshipping culture.

lass="word-wrap-span">There is a new “traditionalist” lass="word-wrap-span">backlash against “lass="word-wrap-span">Modern” women, as a result of a moral panic about lass="word-wrap-span">The loss of culture in lass="word-wrap-span">The face of globalisation. “lass="word-wrap-span">Modern” women are lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Cultural lass="word-wrap-span">Enemy No. 1. lass="word-wrap-span">Village elders have issued bans on women wearing jeans or using mobiles. lass="word-wrap-span">Huge numbers of women are dropping out of lass="word-wrap-span">The workforce lass="word-wrap-span">largely because of lass="word-wrap-span">The absence of safe working conditions. lass="word-wrap-span">The way out is noisy public protest and forming collectives. lass="word-wrap-span">Many women are forging ahead, making lass="word-wrap-span">The “traditionalists” ever more lass="word-wrap-span">furious about westernised “feminazis”.

* * *

lass="word-wrap-span">Banned, lass="word-wrap-span">Banned, lass="word-wrap-span">Banned!

An lass="word-wrap-span">excerpt from “lass="word-wrap-span">Why I Am a lass="word-wrap-span">Liberal” by Sagarika Ghose (lass="word-wrap-span">Penguin lass="word-wrap-span">Random lass="word-wrap-span">House, 2018).

lass="word-wrap-span">How many bans are there today anyway? lass="word-wrap-span">How many aspects of our behaviour are policed?

lass="word-wrap-span">Want to eat tenderloin in lass="word-wrap-span">Maharashtra? lass="word-wrap-span">Sorry, it’s banned.

lass="word-wrap-span">Want to read Salman lass="word-wrap-span">Rushdie’s lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Satanic lass="word-wrap-span">Verses? lass="word-wrap-span">Sorry, it’s banned.

lass="word-wrap-span">Living in lass="word-wrap-span">Gujarat and want to read the lass="word-wrap-span">book lass="word-wrap-span">Great lass="word-wrap-span">Soul by lass="word-wrap-span">Joseph Lelyveld? lass="word-wrap-span">Sorry, it’s banned.

lass="word-wrap-span">Want to see the movie lass="word-wrap-span">Fifty lass="word-wrap-span">Shades of lass="word-wrap-span">Grey? lass="word-wrap-span">Sorry, it hasn’t been cleared by the lass="word-wrap-span">Central lass="word-wrap-span">Board of lass="word-wrap-span">Film lass="word-wrap-span">Certification.

lass="word-wrap-span">Living in lass="word-wrap-span">Gujarat and want to see the film Fanaa? lass="word-wrap-span">Sorry, that was also banned in lass="word-wrap-span">Gujarat.

lass="word-wrap-span">Want to see the play ‘Mi Nathuram Godse Boltoy’? lass="word-wrap-span">Sorry, that was once banned too.

lass="word-wrap-span">Does Priya Pillai of lass="word-wrap-span">Greenpeace want to voice her views in London? lass="word-wrap-span">Sorry, she was once banned from travelling.

lass="word-wrap-span">Want to see lass="word-wrap-span">India’s lass="word-wrap-span">Daughter, a lass="word-wrap-span">documentary on the Nirbhaya rape case? lass="word-wrap-span">Sorry, that’s banned from TV telecast.

lass="word-wrap-span">Bans are an lass="word-wrap-span">entirely un-lass="word-wrap-span">Hindu lass="word-wrap-span">Thing. lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">Think about it, is anylass="word-wrap-span">Thing lass="word-wrap-span">Banned in lass="word-wrap-span">Hinduism? lass="word-wrap-span">Almost nolass="word-wrap-span">Thing. lass="word-wrap-span">What’s common between liberal lass="word-wrap-span">Democracy and lass="word-wrap-span">Hindu philosophy? A lass="word-wrap-span">constant search for answers, a quest for knowledge, a starting lass="word-wrap-span">assumption that we don’t—we cannot—know everylass="word-wrap-span">Thing. lass="word-wrap-span">However, governments which are stubbornly lass="word-wrap-span">convinced that they possess lass="word-wrap-span">absolute knowledge lass="word-wrap-span">implement policies through lass="word-wrap-span">Bans and lass="word-wrap-span">diktats. lass="word-wrap-span">People of lass="word-wrap-span">goodwill may on occasion differ on answers and on specific public policies. lass="word-wrap-span">Democracy provides a platform to legally and lass="word-wrap-span">formally negotiate a common ground in a particular context, which is open to change as the context changes. lass="word-wrap-span">Hindu philosophy is full of such debates and in these debates there is little lass="word-wrap-span">absolute knowledge or any lass="word-wrap-span">absolute certainty of truth.

lass="word-wrap-span">Yet, those who believe in supreme government power believe lass="word-wrap-span">They have all lass="word-wrap-span">The answers and are lass="word-wrap-span">The sole repositories of knowledge. lass="word-wrap-span">They believe lass="word-wrap-span">They have seen lass="word-wrap-span">The light. lass="word-wrap-span">Self-doubt does not trouble lass="word-wrap-span">Them. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Big lass="word-wrap-span">State believes it has ultimate knowledge about what’s good for lass="word-wrap-span">The people. lass="word-wrap-span">The people have to simply be lass="word-wrap-span">goaded and lass="word-wrap-span">herded into obeying lass="word-wrap-span">The mai-baap sarkar’s* wishes. lass="word-wrap-span">Any questioning or lass="word-wrap-span">disagreement is not only plain wrong or agenda-driven but lass="word-wrap-span">equivalent to treason.

Is the strength of a so-called strong government to be defined by how lass="word-wrap-span">brutally it demolishes citizens’ personal freedom, privacy and personal choices? Yes, the benefits of yoga are undeniable, but should the taxpayer’s money be spent on yoga events on a national scale? In 2016, in the lass="word-wrap-span">aftermath of demonetisation, lass="word-wrap-span">Prime lass="word-wrap-span">Minister Modi praised a lass="word-wrap-span">Surat couple who chose a low-cost wedding and managed to marry by paying only Rs 500.

lass="word-wrap-span">Don’t citizens have the choice about whether they want meagre or lass="word-wrap-span">extravagant weddings? lass="word-wrap-span">Can citizens in a democracy be forced into lass="word-wrap-span">austerity as a moral command? lass="word-wrap-span">Why should citizens be lass="word-wrap-span">instructed by the prime minister on their behavioural choices? It is as if only the government and the prime minister know what is in the best interests of over a billion mindless children who lass="word-wrap-span">apparently believe they are citizens of lass="word-wrap-span">India! It is an infantilising of an lass="word-wrap-span">electorate lass="word-wrap-span">empowered to vote!

[…]

lass="word-wrap-span">Why We lass="word-wrap-span">Should be lass="word-wrap-span">Proud to be lass="word-wrap-span">Liberal and lass="word-wrap-span">Indian

lass="word-wrap-span">The drive across lass="word-wrap-span">The world is how to make governments more transparent and lass="word-wrap-span">accountable to citizens. In sharp contrast today lass="word-wrap-span">The reverse is true in lass="word-wrap-span">India. It is citizens who are forced to be more and more transparent and lass="word-wrap-span">accountable to governments. lass="word-wrap-span">The animating spirit of this government seems to be: that citizens are by nature lass="word-wrap-span">corrupt, lass="word-wrap-span">They’re lass="word-wrap-span">hiding personal information, lass="word-wrap-span">They lass="word-wrap-span">evade taxes, lass="word-wrap-span">They’re slothful, lawless, don’t do enough yoga and must be reined in and made lass="word-wrap-span">accountable to lass="word-wrap-span">The government. lass="word-wrap-span">The government in so-called “lass="word-wrap-span">New lass="word-wrap-span">India” is laying out a lass="word-wrap-span">New lass="word-wrap-span">ethical code for its citizens: ”lass="word-wrap-span">Disclose everything if you have nothing to lass="word-wrap-span">hide.” lass="word-wrap-span">Yet at lass="word-wrap-span">The same time lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">New code for lass="word-wrap-span">The government is “lass="word-wrap-span">Disclose nothing” to citizens, since lass="word-wrap-span">They are simply not worthy of trust. […]

lass="word-wrap-span">Citizens of lass="word-wrap-span">India, lass="word-wrap-span">You are not guilty lass="word-wrap-span">Just because lass="word-wrap-span">You lawfully exercise personal choices. lass="word-wrap-span">Just because lass="word-wrap-span">You happen to lass="word-wrap-span">disagree with the government does not make lass="word-wrap-span">You guilty. lass="word-wrap-span">You are guilty only if lass="word-wrap-span">You break the law, not if lass="word-wrap-span">You offend the government’s lass="word-wrap-span">ideological certainties or refuse to be a lass="word-wrap-span">cheerleader of the government of the day.

lass="word-wrap-span">The liberal view is lass="word-wrap-span">The state exists to safeguard lass="word-wrap-span">The individual. lass="word-wrap-span">The individual is not a soldier of state power. lass="word-wrap-span">The rights of lass="word-wrap-span">The individual lass="word-wrap-span">Therefore become lass="word-wrap-span">The supreme consideration because liberty is lass="word-wrap-span">The supreme good. lass="word-wrap-span">Those street mobs who are trying to take away this freedom are not protectors of identity, lass="word-wrap-span">They are just terrorists peddling fear. […]

lass="word-wrap-span">Defending personal freedom is also, in many ways, a defence of lass="word-wrap-span">Indian traditions. lass="word-wrap-span">Attacking personal freedoms is profoundly anti-lass="word-wrap-span">Indian. […] lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">essence of lass="word-wrap-span">Indian spiritual and cultural lass="word-wrap-span">heritage is lass="word-wrap-span">The ultimate lass="word-wrap-span">individualistic pursuit of self-realisation. lass="word-wrap-span">Recognition and respect for personal freedom in a modern polity is an extension of that age-old wisdom.

lass="word-wrap-span">Those who are attacking the mainsprings of lass="word-wrap-span">Indianness, who are hacking away at the deep roots of liberalism in our soil and flying in the face of generation upon generation of free thinkers and lass="word-wrap-span">iconoclasts are lass="word-wrap-span">ironically posing as the so-called defenders of “lass="word-wrap-span">Indian” identity. It is the free minds who are being attacked by lass="word-wrap-span">fearful minds.

___________

* paternalistic government
